children.definition: Base financial metric from which excess cash flow is calculated, typically consolidated net income for the fiscal year or consolidated EBITDA. The choice of starting point materially affects the sweep amount: net-income-based ECF captures only bottom-line profitability, while EBITDA-based ECF starts higher and relies on deductions to reach the swept amount.
children.name: Starting Point

children.definition: Standard non-cash addback: depreciation and amortization expense. Universal inclusion.
children.name: Depreciation & Amortization

children.definition: Stock-based compensation, unrealized losses, impairment charges, deferred financing cost amortization, and other non-cash items. Scope varies significantly across CAs.
children.name: Other Non-Cash Charges
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (Leverage Ratios); DLS Preferred Row 69 (Voluntary Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments)

children.definition: Non-cash charges added back to CNI to approximate cash flow: depreciation, amortization, non-cash interest expense, stock-based compensation, unrealized mark-to-market losses, impairment charges.
children.name: ECF Addbacks
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 46 (ECF Sweep – Percentages); Review Template Row 47 (ECF Sweep – Threshold); Review Template Row 48 (ECF Sweep – Credits)

children.definition: Scheduled amortization of term loans and other funded debt. Universal deduction.
children.name: Scheduled Debt Payments
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (Leverage Ratios); DLS Preferred Row 69 (Voluntary Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments)

children.definition: CapEx paid with internally generated cash (not financed). 65.3% prevalence as ECF deduction.
children.name: Capital Expenditures (Internally Funded)
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 76 (Capex)

children.definition: Deduction from excess cash flow for cash taxes actually paid (or estimated to be payable) during the fiscal year, reducing the amount available for mandatory prepayment. Ensures that the sweep captures only truly excess cash by accounting for the borrower's actual tax obligations, rather than sweeping funds needed to satisfy tax liabilities.
children.name: Cash Taxes Paid
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (Leverage Ratios); DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 72 (a. EBITDA)

children.definition: Increases in working capital are deducted; decreases may be added back. 40.8% prevalence. Direction of adjustment is critical for accuracy.
children.name: Working Capital Changes
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 86 (h. Available Amount); DLS Preferred Row 88 (j. Other Negative Covenants)

children.definition: Cash interest paid during the period. Included in most ECF definitions.
children.name: Cash Interest Expense
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (Leverage Ratios); DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 72 (a. EBITDA)

children.definition: Cash expenditures deducted from the ECF calculation: scheduled debt payments, capital expenditures (funded internally), cash taxes paid, working capital increases. Reduces the base ECF before percentage is applied.
children.name: ECF Definitional Deductions
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 45 (ECF Sweep – Holiday); Review Template Row 46 (ECF Sweep – Percentages); Review Template Row 47 (ECF Sweep – Threshold)

children.definition: Modifications to the excess cash flow calculation that give effect to acquisitions, dispositions, and other material transactions as if they had occurred at the beginning of the measurement period. These adjustments align the ECF computation with the borrower's current-state operations, preventing windfall sweep amounts or artificial reductions from mid-period transactions.
children.name: Pro Forma Adjustments
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 9 (Accordion); DLS Preferred Row 14 (Delayed Draw Term Loans); DLS Preferred Row 15 (Limited Condition Acquisition)

children.definition: The defined term establishing the Excess Cash Flow calculation. ECF = (CNI + non-cash charges + WC decreases + non-cash disposition losses) minus (non-cash credits + capex + principal debt payments + non-cash disposition gains + WC increases + long-term liability payments + cash investments + cash restricted payments + financing fees + cash for prior non-cash charges + prepayment premiums + contracted/planned expenditure reserves + lease adjustments + cash tax adjustments). Per Learning Material: 'In the current market, there are many deductions that result in ECF being a very small amount.'
children.name: Excess Cash Flow Definition

ECF sweep holiday (deferral of first payment)
Minimum ECF threshold before sweep required
Reinvestment period for asset sale proceeds
Leverage-based step-downs for asset sale sweep
Declined mandatory prepayment proceeds build Available Amount

negotiation_spectrum.preferred_position: Term Loan Facility: 75% of excess cash flow (calculation of excess cash flow to be net of certain investments and restricted payments, certain prepayments of debt, acquisitions and capital expenditures (including contracted acquisitions and planned capital expenditures expected to be consummated within 365 days) with [Total/Senior] net leverage-based step-downs to 50% at [ ]x inside Closing Date [

children.definition_source: Intro Guide (Signal), ECF Sweep Example: detailed Excess Cash Flow definition. Learning Material: 'definition of Excess Cash Flow has many deductions that result in ECF being a very small amount.'

children.definition: Market standard initial sweep rate. Default for most BSL and PC transactions.
children.name: 50% Standard
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 46 (ECF Sweep – Percentages)

children.definition: DLS bank-preferred rate. Common in pre-2018 and higher-risk deals.
children.name: 75% Aggressive
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 48 (ECF Sweep – Credits)

children.definition: Typically seen in large-cap or sponsor-friendly transactions.
children.name: 25% Borrower-Friendly

children.definition: Full ECF sweep. Distressed, restructuring, or special situations. No retained ECF for builder basket.
children.name: 100% Distressed/Special Situations
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 93 (o. Voting)

children.definition: Starting percentage of Excess Cash Flow applied to mandatory prepayment of term loans. Range: 25% (borrower-friendly) to 75-100% (aggressive/distressed). The retained portion (100% - sweep%) flows to the builder basket, creating the fundamental tension between deleveraging and flexibility.
children.name: ECF Sweep Percentage

negotiation_spectrum.aggressive_position: 50% step downs to 25% and 0% Dollar for dollar credit for prepayments of any other pari passu debt not incurred under the Credit Facility (i.e. under a ratio or dollar basket) Dollar for dollar credit applies to prepayments made with revolving loans Dollar for dollar credit for cap ex, investments, RPs, etc Dollar for dollar credit for open market purchases Dollar threshold for minimum ECF needed

key_negotiation_points: Deductions from ECF (investments, RPs, capex, acquisitions)
ECF sweep holiday (deferral of first payment)
Minimum ECF threshold before sweep required
Reinvestment period for asset sale proceeds
Leverage-based step-downs for asset sale sweep
Declined mandatory prepayment proceeds build Available Amount
negotiation_spectrum.market_position: Market standard for mandatory prepayments (ecf sweep + asset sale sweep) reflects a negotiated middle ground, with specific terms varying by deal size, leverage profile, and competitive dynamics.
negotiation_spectrum.preferred_position: Term Loan Facility: 75% of excess cash flow (calculation of excess cash flow to be net of certain investments and restricted payments, certain prepayments of debt, acquisitions and capital expenditures (including contracted acquisitions and planned capital expenditures expected to be consummated within 365 days) with [Total/Senior] net leverage-based step-downs to 50% at [ ]x inside Closing Date [

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 5 (Commitment Percentage); DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 83 (Dispositions); Review Template Row 46 (ECF Sweep – Percentages); Review Template Row 47 (ECF Sweep – Threshold)

children.definition: 50% -> 25% -> 0% at First Lien Net Leverage thresholds (e.g., 4.5x -> 4.0x). Most common structure. Two step-downs = 60.4% of market.
children.name: Typical 50/25/0 Pattern

children.definition: 75% -> 50% -> 25% -> 0% with more granular tiers. Seen in aggressive lender structures. 31.2% of three-plus step deals.
children.name: Three-Tier (75/50/25/0)

children.definition: Flat sweep percentage regardless of leverage. Maximum lender protection.
children.name: No Step-Downs (Flat)

red_flags.text: No ECF sweep step-down -- 100% sweep at all leverage levels reduces builder basket growth to zero from ECF

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 73 (b. Covenant); Review Template Row 138 (Pricing)

children.definition: Percentage reduces at specified leverage ratio thresholds. Standard pattern: 50% -> 25% -> 0% at descending leverage levels.
children.name: Leverage-Based Step-Downs
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 41 (d. Maximum leverage); DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 73 (b. Covenant)

children.definition: Only counts first-lien secured debt, nets cash.
children.name: First Lien Net Leverage
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (Leverage Ratios); DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 73 (b. Covenant)

children.definition: Includes all debt classes, nets cash. Standard BSL approach.
children.name: Total Net Leverage
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 86 (h. Available Amount); Review Template Row 46 (ECF Sweep – Percentages)

children.definition: Counts all secured debt, nets cash. 20% of deals, within the ecf step-down schedule framework of mandatory prepayments.
children.name: Senior Secured Net Leverage
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 4 (b. Funded Debt at Closing); DLS Preferred Row 9 (Accordion); DLS Preferred Row 13 (Leverage Ratios)

children.definition: Includes all debt, no cash netting. Most lender-protective.
children.name: Total Leverage (Gross)
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 86 (h. Available Amount); Review Template Row 46 (ECF Sweep – Percentages)

children.definition: The leverage ratio used for step-down triggers. First Lien Net Leverage is most common and borrower-friendly. Total Net, Senior Secured, and Total Leverage are progressively more lender-friendly.
children.name: Leverage Metric
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 86 (h. Available Amount); Review Template Row 46 (ECF Sweep – Percentages)

children.definition: Specific ratio levels triggering each step-down. PC Term Comparison standard: 0.5x and 1.0x inside closing leverage. Expert evidence varies: Geneva 5.45x/5.2x (PC), Viavi 3.6x/3.1x (BSL), reflecting market differences.

ecf_threshold_bsl.value: Greater of dollar amount and 10% EBITDA (Viavi: $25M/10%); Red Rock: none

ecf_threshold_lmm.value: None or no more than 5% of EBITDA

children.name: Leverage Thresholds
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 86 (h. Available Amount); DLS Preferred Row 93 (o. Voting)

children.definition: ECF percentage reduced by a fixed amount (e.g., 5%) for each 0.25x leverage reduction below starting level. Emerging innovation providing continuous rather than discrete step-downs.
children.name: Performance Ratchet
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 86 (h. Available Amount)

children.definition: Leverage-based reductions in ECF sweep percentage as borrower deleverages. Step-downs to 0% allow all ECF to flow to builder basket. The leverage metric and thresholds are critical negotiation points.
children.name: ECF Step-Down Schedule

red_flags.text: No ECF sweep step-down -- 100% sweep at all leverage levels reduces builder basket growth to zero from ECF

children.definition_source: Review Template Row 46 (ECF Sweep – Percentages)

children.definition: Aggressive formulation simultaneously lowers prepayments AND increases builder basket growth from retained ECF.
children.name: Deduction Formulation Type

children.definition: Dollar-for-dollar credit for voluntary prepayments of pari passu debt during the fiscal year. 89.8% prevalence -- most universal deduction. Prevents double-counting. Bank preferred: limited to term loans and revolving loans with permanent commitment reduction.
children.name: Voluntary Prepayment Credit

red_flags.text: No voluntary prepayment credit in ECF sweep -- borrower cannot reduce ECF sweep obligation by making voluntary prepayments during the year

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 69 (Voluntary Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 86 (h. Available Amount)

children.definition: Credit for capital expenditures financed with internally generated cash flow (not debt-funded). 65.3% prevalence. Growth investment protection. Scope varies: maintenance + growth (broad) vs. growth only (narrow).
children.name: Capital Expenditure Credit
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 86 (h. Available Amount)

children.definition: Credit for cash-funded permitted acquisitions and investments during the period. 51.0% prevalence. M&A flexibility. Often requires that the acquisition be consummated (not merely committed).
children.name: Permitted Acquisition Credit

children.definition: Credit for cash-funded permitted investments. 63.3% prevalence. Business expansion flexibility. May include intercompany investments, JV investments, and financial asset purchases.
children.name: Permitted Investment Credit
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 81 (Investments)

children.definition: Credit for restricted payments made during the period (dividends, distributions, share repurchases). Links ECF sweep to RP covenant. Controversial: reduces deleveraging in exchange for shareholder returns.
children.name: Restricted Payment Credit
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 84 (Restricted Payments)

children.definition: Credit for increases in working capital during the period. 40.8% prevalence. Protects businesses with seasonal or growing working capital needs.
children.name: Working Capital Increase Credit
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 76 (e. Capex); DLS Preferred Row 86 (h. Available Amount)

children.definition: Credit for prepayments of junior or subordinated debt. Controversial -- should NOT reduce first lien obligation according to bank-preferred terms. If permitted, allows borrower to divert ECF from senior to junior lenders.
children.name: Junior Debt Prepayment Credit
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 69 (Voluntary Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 85 (g. Restricted Debt Prepayments)

children.definition: Whether deductions reduce ECF calculation (55%, pre-percentage) vs. reduce prepayment amount (30%, post-percentage) vs. borrower election. Post-percentage application is strictly more borrower-favorable.
children.name: Deduction Application Method

children.definition: Whether unused deduction credits can be carried forward to subsequent fiscal years. 15% prevalence. Duration: unlimited, 1-year, 2-year. Further erodes the sweep by allowing credit accumulation over time.
children.name: Excess Credit Carryforward
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 86 (h. Available Amount)

children.definition: Dollar-for-dollar deductions from ECF calculation or prepayment amount. Average 6-8 deduction categories. THE critical drafting distinction: traditional deductions reduce ECF definition (smaller retained ECF, smaller builder); aggressive dollar-for-dollar credits reduce prepayment amount (retained ECF stays high, builder grows more). 80% prevalence.
children.name: ECF Deduction Framework
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 46 (ECF Sweep – Percentages); Review Template Row 47 (ECF Sweep – Threshold); Review Template Row 48 (ECF Sweep – Credits)

children.definition: Fixed dollar amount ($1M-$5M typical). Simple and predictable.
children.name: Dollar-Only Threshold
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 14 (Delayed Draw Term Loans); DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 93 (o. Voting)

children.definition: Greater of $X and Y% of EBITDA. Most common: $2.5M / 10% EBITDA. Scales with borrower size. Expert evidence: Geneva $50M/10%, Scientific Games $45M/10%, Viavi $25M/10%.
children.name: Greater-Of Structure
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 47 (ECF Sweep – Threshold)

children.definition: No minimum -- every dollar of ECF swept. Maximum lender protection. Red Rock BSL example.
children.name: No Threshold
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 47 (ECF Sweep – Threshold)

children.definition: Whether only the excess above threshold must be paid, or the entire ECF amount once threshold is exceeded. Excess-only is borrower-favorable; cliff approach is lender-favorable. Iridium example: only the excess.
children.name: Excess-Only Mechanic
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 86 (h. Available Amount); DLS Preferred Row 93 (o. Voting)

children.definition: Dollar threshold below which no ECF mandatory prepayment is required. Per PC Term Comparison: Aggressive UMM/BSLR 5-10% of EBITDA; otherwise none or no more than 5%. Per Learning Material: 'a de minimis threshold based on the ECF prepayment amount (as opposed to the amount of ECF) means the borrower could always evade the ECF sweep with a large enough voluntary prepayment.' Bank position: de minimis amounts should not build retained ECF for the Available Amount.

review_ref.term: Negative Covenants – Dispositions – De Minimis Threshold
Negative Covenants – Transactions with Affiliates – De Minimis Threshold

children.definition_source: PC Term Comparison: 'De minimis threshold: Aggressive UMM/BSLR 5-10% of EBITDA. Otherwise: none or no more than 5%.' Learning Material: 'flag de minimis exclusion amount.'
pc_ref: : 'De minimis threshold: Aggressive UMM/BSLR 5-10% of EBITDA. Otherwise: none or no more than 5%.' Learning Material: 'flag de minimis exclusion amount.'

children.definition: ECF sweep applied pro rata among all term loans and pari passu debt. Standard approach. Ensures equal treatment of lender classes.
children.name: Pro Rata Application
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 7 (Letters of Credit); DLS Preferred Row 16 (Refinancing Debt); DLS Preferred Row 72 (a. EBITDA)

children.definition: Borrower may direct ECF sweep to specific tranches. Emerging in sponsor-friendly deals. Allows strategic prepayment of higher-cost debt.
children.name: Borrower-Directed Application

children.definition: Whether ECF prepayments reduce future scheduled amortization installments. If yes, ECF sweep effectively buys amortization relief.
children.name: Amortization Schedule Credit

children.definition: Whether pari passu debt outside the credit agreement (e.g., incremental equivalent debt, pari notes) participates in the ECF sweep pro rata. Standard: yes, all pari debt shares.
children.name: Pari Passu Debt Inclusion
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 16 (Refinancing Debt); DLS Preferred Row 69 (Voluntary Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments)

children.definition: How ECF sweep proceeds are applied across term loan tranches and other pari passu debt. Pro rata application is standard, but borrower-directed application is emerging in sponsor-friendly deals.

declined_proceeds_lmm.value: Retained by borrower (conservative: do not build AA)

children.name: ECF Application of Proceeds

children.name: Payment Date
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 93 (o. Voting)

children.definition: When the first ECF sweep occurs. First full fiscal year after closing, second fiscal year, stub year. Delayed first payment = ECF holiday.
children.name: First ECF Payment
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 45 (ECF Sweep – Holiday)

children.definition: The fiscal period over which ECF is measured. Standard: annual (full fiscal year). Some CAs permit semi-annual calculations. Stub periods at closing may be excluded.
children.name: Calculation Period
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments)

children.definition: When the ECF sweep payment is due, what fiscal period it covers, and when the first sweep occurs. Standard: annual, within 90-120 days of fiscal year end, commencing with first full fiscal year after closing.
children.name: ECF Timing & Calculation Period

children.definition_source: Review Template Row 45 (ECF Sweep – Holiday)

children.definition: Number of fiscal years of holiday. Standard: 1 full fiscal year. Some aggressive deals: 2 fiscal years. Stub periods typically not counted.
children.name: Holiday Duration

children.definition: Whether the holiday is tied to the closing date or a specific fiscal year end. Closing-date-based: commencing first full fiscal year ending after closing. Fixed: commencing with fiscal year ending [specific date].
children.name: Start Date Reference

children.definition: The first ECF sweep is calculated for the first full fiscal year after the closing date. Per DLS Preferred: 'First excess cash flow prepayment required for the fiscal year ended [__], 20[__].' Per Learning Material: 'Confirm first ECF period, especially if closing date may occur toward the beginning of a fiscal year.' DLS alternative includes a holiday on the first ECF period. Neutron extraction context (ECF_SWEEP_HOLIDAY): The initial period during which no ECF sweep is required. The ECF sweep holiday provides the borrower with an initial grace period during which no excess cash flow prepayment is required. This is typically structured as the first full fiscal year after closing, giving the borrower time to stabilize operations post-acquisition before cash sweep obligations begin.

ECF_SWEEP_HOLIDAY.label: ECF Sweep Holiday
ECF_SWEEP_HOLIDAY.description: The initial period during which no ECF sweep is required
ECF_SWEEP_HOLIDAY.backgroundExplanation: The ECF sweep holiday provides the borrower with an initial grace period during which no excess cash flow prepayment is required. This is typically structured as the first full fiscal year after closing, giving the borrower time to stabilize operations post-acquisition before cash sweep obligations begin. The holiday allows the sponsor to retain operating cash during the critical integration period. Holidays typically range from 1-2 fiscal years, with 1 year (4 quarters) being most common in the market. The agreement language will NOT explicitly make reference to a "Holiday" and instead will just make reference to when the first excess cash flow prepayment is to be made.
ECF_SWEEP_HOLIDAY.summary_used: The initial period during which no ECF sweep is required. The ECF sweep holiday provides the borrower with an initial grace period during which no excess cash flow prepayment is required. This is typically structured as the first full fiscal year after closing, giving the borrower time to stabilize operations post-acquisition before cash sweep obligations begin.

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred row 70: 'First excess cash flow prepayment required for the fiscal year ended [__].' DLS alt: 'Holiday on first ECF period.' Learning Material: 'Confirm first ECF period.'

children.definition: Whether voluntary prepayments reduce ECF sweep obligation on a dollar-for-dollar basis. 89.8% prevalence. Most universal credit type.
children.name: ECF Sweep Credit

red_flags.text: No voluntary prepayment credit in ECF sweep -- borrower cannot reduce ECF sweep obligation by making voluntary prepayments during the year

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 7 (Letters of Credit)

children.definition: Whether the same voluntary prepayment builds incremental facility capacity via the prepayment prong. Allows the borrower to 'recycle' capacity: prepay, get ECF credit, and rebuild debt capacity simultaneously.

ecf_credits_bsl.value: Broad credits (Viavi: capex, acquisitions, investments, RPs, planned expenditures); Red Rock: no credits at all

ecf_credits_cmm.value: Voluntary prepayments of pari debt; discuss capex/investment credits with clients

ecf_credits_umm.value: Dollar-for-dollar credits for capex, investments, RPs, voluntary prepayments; carryforward to subsequent years

ecf_stepdowns_bsl.value: Tighter leverage triggers than private credit (Viavi: 3.6x/3.1x FL vs. Geneva: 5.45x/5.2x)

ecf_stepdowns_lmm.value: 0.5x/1.0x inside closing leverage; no flex to remove

children.name: Incremental Capacity Credit
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); Review Template Row 24 (Incremental Amount – freebie); Review Template Row 25 (Incremental Amount – prepayments)

children.definition: Whether the voluntary prepayment reduces leverage sufficiently to trigger a step-down in the ECF sweep percentage, creating a cascade effect: prepay -> lower leverage -> lower sweep % -> more retained ECF -> more builder.
children.name: Leverage Impact for Step-Downs
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 73 (b. Covenant); DLS Preferred Row 86 (h. Available Amount)

children.definition: Triple interaction: voluntary prepayments simultaneously (1) reduce ECF sweep obligation via dollar-for-dollar credit, (2) may build incremental capacity via the prepayment prong, and (3) reduce leverage for step-down purposes. 58.1% prevalence. This triangle is one of the most powerful strategic levers.
children.name: Voluntary Prepayment Interaction

children.definition: Mechanism allowing unused ECF sweep credits to carry forward to subsequent fiscal years. Permits borrower to offset future ECF sweep obligations with prior-period voluntary prepayments or other credits not yet applied. Reduces effective sweep percentage over time.
children.name: ECF Carry-Forward
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 76 (e. Capex); Review Template Row 46 (ECF Sweep – Percentages); Review Template Row 47 (ECF Sweep – Threshold)

children.definition: The excess cash flow mandatory prepayment mechanism requiring a percentage of annual ECF to be applied to prepay term loans. Per DLS Preferred: '75% of excess cash flow with leverage-based step-downs.' Per Learning Material: 'Prepayment amount is usually 50% of ECF, with stepdowns to 25% and 0% at 0.5x below and 1.0x below closing date leverage ratios.' The retained portion feeds the Available Amount. In the current market, many deductions result in ECF being very small or zero, but lenders still expect the provision.

market_benchmarks.pctc_conservative: non or no more than 5%; 0.5x/1.0x or 0.75x/1.5x inside closing total/first lien/secured leverage.
market_benchmarks.pctc_umm_bsl: typically between 5-10% of EBITDA; typically 0.5 and 1.0 inside closing first lien leverage (for a 1L deal)

children.definition: Treatment of non-cash consideration received in asset dispositions for purposes of calculating net proceeds subject to the mandatory prepayment sweep. Non-cash consideration (equity, notes, earnouts) is typically excluded from net proceeds until converted to cash, at which point the conversion proceeds become subject to the prepayment obligation.
children.name: Non-Cash Consideration

children.definition: Definition of Net Cash Proceeds from asset sales. Gross proceeds minus reasonable fees/expenses, applicable taxes, amounts required to repay secured debt, and contractual obligations. The defined scope determines how much actually triggers the sweep.
children.name: Net Cash Proceeds Definition
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 41 (Asset Sale Sweep - Coverage)

children.definition: Time for reinvestment without binding commitment. Standard: 365 days (BSL) or 12-18 months (PC). UMM/aggressive: 450-540 days. Expert evidence: Geneva 18 months, Viavi 450 days.
children.name: Initial Reinvestment Period
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 14 (Delayed Draw Term Loans); DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); Review Template Row 41 (Asset Sale Sweep - Coverage)

children.definition: Additional time if binding commitment, letter of intent, or purchase agreement is in place. Standard: 180 days.

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 14 (Delayed Draw Term Loans); DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 93 (o. Voting)

children.definition: Replacement assets of the same or similar type as those disposed. Standard formulation.
children.name: Assets Useful in Business
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 44 (Business MAC)

children.definition: Permission to apply asset sale net proceeds to capital expenditures as an alternative to mandatory prepayment of the credit facility, within the reinvestment period. Allows the borrower to redeploy disposition proceeds into productive assets that maintain or enhance the business, rather than being forced to deleverage when reinvestment opportunities exist.
children.name: Capital Expenditures
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (Leverage Ratios); DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 73 (b. Covenant)

children.definition: Permission to apply asset sale net proceeds to permitted acquisitions as an alternative to mandatory prepayment, within the reinvestment period. Enables the borrower to use disposition proceeds for strategic growth through acquisitions rather than being compelled to reduce debt, provided the acquisition satisfies all conditions in the permitted acquisitions framework.
dls_ref: DLS:10:Incremental Term Loans may only be used

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 10 (Incremental Term Loans may only be used); DLS Preferred Row 82 (Permitted Acquisitions)

children.definition: Right of borrower to reinvest net proceeds in business assets within a specified period instead of prepaying debt. 98.3% prevalence -- nearly universal. Standard structure: initial period (365 days) plus extension with commitment (180 days).

Neutron extraction context (ASSET_SALE_THRESHOLD): De minimis thresholds for asset sale sweep, including annual aggregate and per-transaction thresholds with potential grower components. Asset sale thresholds establish de minimis amounts below which the mandatory prepayment sweep does not apply. Two common types exist: (1) annual aggregate thresholds that set a yearly ceiling before sweep triggers, and (2) per-transaction thresholds for individual sales.

ASSET_SALE_THRESHOLD.label: Asset Sale Threshold
ASSET_SALE_THRESHOLD.description: De minimis thresholds for asset sale sweep, including annual aggregate and per-transaction thresholds with potential grower components.
ASSET_SALE_THRESHOLD.backgroundExplanation: Asset sale thresholds establish de minimis amounts below which the mandatory prepayment sweep does not apply. Two common types exist: (1) annual aggregate thresholds that set a yearly ceiling before sweep triggers, and (2) per-transaction thresholds for individual sales. Thresholds often include "grower" components tied to EBITDA or Total Assets, allowing the threshold to increase with the company's size. This flexibility helps growing borrowers manage routine asset sales without constant prepayment obligations. The threshold structure significantly impacts borrower flexibility - high thresholds with growers can effectively neutralize the sweep for many mid-market companies.
ASSET_SALE_THRESHOLD.summary_used: De minimis thresholds for asset sale sweep, including annual aggregate and per-transaction thresholds with potential grower components. Asset sale thresholds establish de minimis amounts below which the mandatory prepayment sweep does not apply. Two common types exist: (1) annual aggregate thresholds that set a yearly ceiling before sweep triggers, and (2) per-transaction thresholds for individual sales.

Per PC Term Comparison: aggressive UMM/BSLR limited to 75% basket, otherwise should include 75%, general, sale-leaseback, and other material baskets.

market_benchmarks.pctc_umm_bsl: Typically limited to the unlimited sales basket (ie the  75% basket)

Hard call vs soft call (repricing only)
Deductions from ECF (investments, RPs, capex, acquisitions)
ECF sweep holiday (deferral of first payment)
Minimum ECF threshold before sweep required
Reinvestment period for asset sale proceeds
Leverage-based step-downs for asset sale sweep
Declined mandatory prepayment proceeds build Available Amount
negotiation_spectrum.market_position: Market standard for voluntary prepayments reflects a negotiated middle ground, with specific terms varying by deal size, leverage profile, and competitive dynamics.
negotiation_spectrum.preferred_position: 100% net cash proceeds from non-ordinary-course asset sales; 6-month reinvestment right with 180-day commitment extension

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred row 70: '100% of net cash proceeds from non-ordinary course asset sales.' PC Term Comparison: 'Baskets Covered: Aggressive UMM/BSLR limited to 75% basket. Otherwise: 75%, general, sale leaseback, de minimis, non-core.' Learning Material Section (1): 'Asset Sale Mandatory Prepayment.'

children.definition: Almost universally 100%. No market variation. Non-negotiable in standard leveraged deals.
children.name: Sweep Percentage
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 86 (h. Available Amount); Review Template Row 41 (Asset Sale Sweep - Coverage); Review Template Row 42 (Asset Sale Sweep - Threshold)

children.definition: Whether based on gross proceeds (75% of deals) or net proceeds after fees (25%). Net basis is borrower-favorable.
children.name: Proceeds Basis
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 7 (Letters of Credit); DLS Preferred Row 14 (Delayed Draw Term Loans); DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments)

children.definition: When prepayment is due. Immediately upon receipt, within 3 business days, within 5 business days. No reinvestment rights -- unlike asset sale sweep.
children.name: Payment Timing
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 93 (o. Voting)

children.definition: Permitted refinancing indebtedness always excluded from sweep. Allows liability management without triggering mandatory prepayment. Critical for repricing and extension transactions.
children.name: Refinancing Exclusion
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 69 (Voluntary Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); Review Template Row 152 (Refinancing)

children.definition: Other debt types excluded from the sweep: capital leases, purchase money debt, incremental facilities (already subject to MFN/conditions), revolving borrowings, letters of credit, intercompany debt.
children.name: Other Permitted Debt Exclusions
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 69 (Voluntary Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 86 (h. Available Amount)

children.definition: Mandatory prepayment triggered by net cash proceeds from non-permitted debt issuances. Per DLS Preferred: '100% of net cash proceeds of debt (excluding permitted debt other than refinancing debt).' Per Learning Material: 'Generally applies only to debt not permitted by the credit agreement, other than Refinancing Facilities. Usually uncontroversial. Should not be subject to right of lenders to decline.'

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred row 70: '100% of net cash proceeds of debt (excluding permitted debt other than refinancing debt).' Learning Material: 'Generally applies only to non-permitted debt. Usually uncontroversial. Should not be subject to lender declination.'

children.definition: What triggers the equity sweep: all equity issuances (65%), IPO-specific (5%), or threshold-based (15%). IPO-specific is most common in PC deals.
children.name: Trigger Event Type
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 86 (h. Available Amount); Review Template Row 47 (ECF Sweep – Threshold)

children.definition: Percentage of equity proceeds swept. 85% at 100%. Some deals: 50% or net of expenses.
children.name: Sweep Percentage
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 86 (h. Available Amount); Review Template Row 41 (Asset Sale Sweep - Coverage); Review Template Row 42 (Asset Sale Sweep - Threshold)

children.definition: Minimum gross proceeds ($50-100M), listing exchange requirements, public float percentage (15-25%). Determines whether IPO triggers full repayment or proportional sweep.
children.name: Qualified IPO Definition
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 86 (h. Available Amount)

children.definition: Whether qualified IPO triggers 100% repayment of all loans or only application of excess proceeds.
children.name: Full Repayment vs Partial
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 45 (ECF Sweep – Holiday); Review Template Row 147 (Mandatory Prepayments); Review Template Row 158 (Commitment/Underwriting Fee)

children.definition: Full repayment or proceeds application upon qualified IPO. Qualified IPO thresholds: $50-100M minimum proceeds, 15-25% public float.
children.name: IPO Sweep Mechanics
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 41 (Asset Sale Sweep - Coverage); Review Template Row 45 (ECF Sweep – Holiday); Review Template Row 46 (ECF Sweep – Percentages)

children.definition: Excluded equity issuances: management/employee equity, sponsor transfers, equity cure contributions, nominal amounts, acquisition funding. Exception scope defines effective sweep breadth.
children.name: Equity Sweep Exceptions
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 84 (f. Restricted Payments); DLS Preferred Row 86 (h. Available Amount)

children.definition: Mandatory prepayment from equity issuance proceeds. Per DLS Preferred row 70: '100% of net cash process of issuances of equity.' DLS alternative: 'No Equity Sweep.' This is an unusual provision -- equity sweeps are more common in private credit than BSL. The provision may trigger full repayment upon a qualifying IPO. Per Learning Material framework: unlike asset sale and ECF sweeps, equity sweeps are not standard and should be flagged when present.

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred row 70: '100% of net cash proceeds of issuances of equity.' DLS alt: 'No Equity Sweep.'

children.definition: Definition of what constitutes a casualty event: fire, flood, explosion, natural disaster, or other event causing loss or destruction of property. Must result in insurance recovery above threshold.
children.name: Casualty Event Definition
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 86 (h. Available Amount)

children.definition: Taking or condemnation by government authority, including voluntary dispositions in lieu of condemnation. Eminent domain proceedings.
children.name: Condemnation Definition
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments)

children.definition: Whether casualty/condemnation proceeds share the same reinvestment period as asset sale proceeds (85% combined) or have separate treatment.
children.name: Reinvestment Rights Sharing
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 93 (o. Voting); Review Template Row 41 (Asset Sale Sweep - Coverage)

children.definition: Mandatory prepayment from insurance proceeds and condemnation/eminent domain awards. Per DLS Preferred row 70: '100% of net cash proceeds from all non-ordinary course asset sales and insurance/condemnation proceeds.' Per Intro Guide: 'asset sale sweep provisions often also pick up proceeds from casualty or recovery events (insurance proceeds or condemnation awards). This could be included within the asset sale sweep or in a separate section.' Typically treated as a subset of the asset sale sweep with the same reinvestment rights.
children.name: Insurance / Condemnation Sweep

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred row 70: 'insurance/condemnation proceeds.' Intro Guide: 'sweep also picks up casualty/recovery events.'

children.definition: Whether CoC triggers mandatory prepayment offer, event of default, or both. Dual trigger (prepay + EoD): 35%. EoD only: 30%. Prepayment only: 5%. BSL typically prepay offer; PC typically EoD.
children.name: Trigger Type
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 47 (ECF Sweep – Threshold)

children.definition: Premium payable on CoC prepayment. Par + call premium, par only, special premium. Time-based schedule: 103% Y1, 102% Y2, 101% Y3, par thereafter.
children.name: Premium Structure

children.definition: When CoC prepayment is due. Immediate upon CoC, upon lender request within notice period, borrower notice period. Offer mechanics may include 10-30 day acceptance window.
children.name: Payment Timing
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 93 (o. Voting)

children.definition: Whether the credit agreement can survive a change of control without triggering prepayment. No portability, limited sponsor transfers, broad portability. Portability is a sponsor-favorable development.
children.name: Portability Provisions
children.definition_source: KCT Cat 3 Item 12

children.definition: Mandatory prepayment or event of default triggered by ownership/control changes. Per DLS Preferred framework: change of control provisions may require prepayment at par or with call premium. Per PC Term Comparison: portability provisions can exempt certain sponsor-to-sponsor transfers. Whether CoC triggers mandatory prepayment, event of default, or both is a key structural choice.
children.name: Change of Control Prepayment

negotiation_spectrum.aggressive_position: Soft call protection in connection with repricings only (subject to carve outs for IPO, change of control transactions and transformative acquisitions/transactions)

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred framework: CoC prepayment provisions. PC Term Comparison: portability exceptions for sponsor transfers.

children.definition: Standard equal treatment across classes. Ensures each lender receives proportionate share.
children.name: Pro Rata Application
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 7 (Letters of Credit); DLS Preferred Row 16 (Refinancing Debt); DLS Preferred Row 72 (a. EBITDA)

children.definition: Structured priority in unitranche or split-lien deals. Applied first to first-out tranche, then RCF, then second-out. Governs who gets paid first.
children.name: First-Out / Second-Out Priority
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 72 (a. EBITDA); DLS Preferred Row 93 (o. Voting)

children.definition: Senior/subordinated interactions. Second lien receives only if first lien lenders decline. Junior debt docs may have separate mandatory prepayment provisions subject to intercreditor waterfall.
children.name: Intercreditor Dynamics
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 147 (Mandatory Prepayments)

children.definition: Tax-driven mandatory payment (Applicable High Yield Discount Obligation). Cannot be declined by lenders. Preserves interest deductibility by requiring minimum cash payments. Overrides normal declination mechanics.
children.name: AHYDO Catch-Up Payment
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 85 (g. Restricted Debt Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 93 (o. Voting)

children.definition: Order within interest rate classes: ABR/base rate loans prepaid first, then SOFR/benchmark loans (to minimize breakage costs). Standard but important operational detail.
children.name: Base Rate / Benchmark Sequencing
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 19 (Swingline); Review Template Row 28 (Incremental – racking and stacking); Review Template Row 143 (Second Lien Facility)

children.definition: How mandatory prepayments are applied across facilities and tranches. Per Learning Material: 'The amount subject to mandatory prepayment may be shared (or offered) among holders of all pari passu secured debt on a pro rata basis.' 'Borrowers counsel may request pro rata sharing of proceeds with second lien and other indebtedness but this is not customary.' Per Intro Guide: application order is typically TL-B first, then TL-A, then RCF. Pro rata within class is standard.
children.name: Application & Waterfall Mechanics

children.definition_source: Learning Material Section (3): 'shared among holders of pari passu secured debt on pro rata basis. Sharing with second lien not customary.' Intro Guide: application order.

children.definition: Where declined proceeds go: borrower retention, reallocation to accepting lenders, cross-facility application, Available Amount builder basket. Builder basket pathway enables value leakage.
children.name: Allocation Waterfall
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 93 (o. Voting); Review Template Row 20 (LCs)

children.definition: Time lenders have to accept or decline the prepayment offer. 5 business days market standard; 3 BDs; 10 BDs. Silence treated as acceptance or declination varies by deal.
children.name: Response Period

children.definition: Prepayments that cannot be declined: AHYDO catch-ups (90%), CoC prepayments (60%), debt sweeps (10%). These override normal declination mechanics.
children.name: Excluded Prepayments
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 69 (Voluntary Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 86 (h. Available Amount)

children.definition: Whether declined first-lien proceeds are offered to second-lien lenders before being retained by the borrower. Provides additional deleveraging opportunity for junior creditors.
children.name: Second Lien Offer-Down
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 25 (Incremental Amount – prepayments); Review Template Row 58 (Financial Covenant – levels); Review Template Row 130 (Change of Control)

children.definition: Whether declined proceeds build the Available Amount/builder basket. Creates the declined_proceeds -> AA -> RP/Investment pathway. Critical leakage vector: lender declines prepayment, proceeds become available for restricted payments.
children.name: Builder Basket Feed

red_flags.text: Declined proceeds feed builder basket -- lender-declined mandatory prepayment proceeds become builder basket capacity for future distributions

children.definition_source: Review Template Row 41 (Asset Sale Sweep - Coverage); Review Template Row 47 (ECF Sweep – Threshold); Review Template Row 48 (ECF Sweep – Credits)

children.definition: Mandatory prepayment proceeds declined by lenders. Per DLS Preferred: 'Lenders may elect to decline any mandatory prepayments (other than from non-permitted debt). Declined proceeds shall be retained by the Borrower.' Per Learning Material: 'Declined Proceeds are commonly added to the Builder Basket.' DLS alternative: 'Declined proceeds build the Available Amount.' If a second lien exists, declined first lien proceeds must be offered to second lien lenders before retention.
children.name: Declined Proceeds Mechanics

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred row 70: 'Lenders may elect to decline. Declined proceeds retained by Borrower.' DLS alt: 'Declined proceeds build the Available Amount.' Learning Material: 'Declined Proceeds are commonly added to the Builder Basket.'

definition: Mandatory prepayment provisions requiring the borrower to prepay term loans upon triggering events. Per Intro Guide: 'Three common types relate to asset sales, excess cash flow and debt incurrence. Lenders typically have the right to reject mandatory prepayments due to asset sales or excess cash flow.' Per DLS Preferred: (1) 75% ECF with leverage step-downs, (2) 100% asset sale proceeds with reinvestment, (3) 100% non-permitted debt proceeds. The ECF sweep was originally intended to force borrowers to use excess cash for debt repayment, but extensive deductions mean borrowers often make no ECF prepayments. Despite this, lenders still expect the provision, particularly in middle market.
name: Mandatory Prepayments

negotiation_spectrum.preferred_position: 75% ECF sweep with leverage step-downs; 100% asset sale and debt proceeds sweep; 100% equity issuance sweep

definition_source: Intro Guide: 'Three common types relate to asset sales, excess cash flow and debt incurrence.' DLS Preferred row 70: '75% of excess cash flow... 100% of net cash proceeds from asset sales... 100% of debt proceeds.' Learning Material: 'Original purpose was to require borrower to use excess cash to prepay debt.'

market_benchmarks.dls_ecf_sweep_pct: 75% of excess cash flow (DLS Preferred position)
market_benchmarks.dls_ecf_stepdowns: Step-downs to 50%, 25%, and 0% at specified levels inside Closing Date leverage
market_benchmarks.dls_asset_sale_sweep: 100% of net cash proceeds from non-ordinary course asset sales
market_benchmarks.dls_reinvestment: Reinvest or commit within 6/12 months with 90/180-day extension
market_benchmarks.dls_debt_sweep: 100% of net cash proceeds of non-permitted debt
market_benchmarks.pctc_ecf_stepdown_umm_bslr: 0.5 and 1.0 inside closing first lien leverage
market_benchmarks.pctc_asset_sale_baskets_other: Should include 75%, general, sale-leaseback, de minimis, non-core baskets
market_benchmarks.pctc_asset_sale_stepdowns: Extremely rare in PC (some go to 50/0 or 75/50/0)
market_benchmarks.source: DLS Preferred row 70, PC Term Comparison Asset Sale Sweep and ECF Sweep sections
